00001 /*
00002 **  File Name:  os_bsp.h
00003 **
00004 **      Copyright (c) 2004-2006, United States government as represented by the
00005 **      administrator of the National Aeronautics Space Administration.
00006 **      All rights reserved. This software(cFE) was created at NASA's Goddard
00007 **      Space Flight Center pursuant to government contracts.
00008 **
00009 **      This software may be used only pursuant to a United States government
00010 **      sponsored project and the United States government may not be charged
00011 **      for use thereof.
00012 **
00013 **  Author:  A. Cudmore
00014 **
00015 **  Purpose:  This file contains BSP support routine prototypes.
00016 **            The BSP routines serve as the "glue" between the RTOS/BSP and
00017 **            the Flight Software. The routines fill gaps that are not
00018 **            really considered part of the OS Abstraction, but are required
00019 **            for the flight software implementation. It is possible that
00020 **            some of these routines could migrate into the OS AL.
00021 **
00022 **  $Log: os_bsp.h  $

00027 **   - Removed calls and references to the BSP based module loader

00031 **  Revision 1.16 2007/09/21 13:31:46EDT rjmcgraw 
00032 **  Added prototypes for GetTimerTicksPerSecond and GetTimerLow32Rollover
00033 **  Revision 1.15 2007/05/30 10:26:06EDT apcudmore

00035 **   - BSP routine to attach processor exceptions

00068 ** Definitions for BSP PANIC types

00071 #define OS_BSP_PANIC_VOLATILE_DISK   2
00072 #define OS_BSP_PANIC_MEMORY_ALLOC    3
00073 #define OS_BSP_PANIC_NONVOL_DISK     4
00074 #define OS_BSP_PANIC_STARTUP_SEM     5
00075 #define OS_BSP_PANIC_CORE_APP        6
00076 #define OS_BSP_PANIC_GENERAL_FAILURE 7

00095 /*
00096 ** BSP entry point and reset routines
00097 */
00098 extern void          OS_BSPMain(int ModeId, char *StartupFilePath);
00099 
00100 /*
00101 ** OS_BSPMain is the entry point that the real time OS calls to start our
00102 ** software. This routine will do any BSP/OS specific setup, then call the
00103 ** entrypoint of the flight software ( i.e. the cFE main entry point ).
00104 ** The flight software (i.e. cFE ) should not call this routine.
00105 */
00106 
00107 extern void         OS_BSPGetTime(OS_time_t *LocalTime);
00108 /* This call gets the local time from the hardware on the Vxworks system
00109  * on the mcp750s
00110  * on the other os/hardware setup, it will get the time the normal way */
00111 
00112 
00113 extern void          OS_BSPRestart(uint32 resetType);
00114 /*
00115 ** OS_BSPRestart is the entry point back to the BSP to restart the processor.
00116 ** The flight software calls this routine to restart the processor.
00117 */
00118 
00119 
00120 extern uint32        OS_BSPGetRestartType(uint32 *restartSubType );
00121 /*
00122 ** OS_BSPGetRestartType returns the last reset type and if a pointer to a valid
00123 ** memory space is passed in, it returns the reset sub-type in that memory.
00124 ** Right now the reset types are application specific. For the cFE they
00125 ** are defined in the cfe_es.h file.
00126 */
00127

00131 ** This is a BSP specific cache flush routine
00132 */

00135 /*
00136 ** OS_BSPGetProcessorId returns the CPU ID as defined by the specific board
00137 ** and BSP.

00147 extern uint32 OS_BSPGet_Timer_Tick(void);
00148 /*
00149 ** OS_BSPGet_Timer_Tick returns the underlying OS timer tick value
00150 ** It is used for the performance monitoring software
00151 */
00152 
00153 extern uint32 OS_BSPGetTimerTicksPerSecond(void);
00154 /*
00155 ** OS_BSPGetTimerTicksPerSecond provides the resolution of the least significant
00156 ** 32 bits of the 64 bit time stamp returned by OS_BSPGet_Timebase in timer
00157 ** ticks per second.  The timer resolution for accuracy should not be any slower
00158 ** than 1000000 ticks per second or 1 us per tick
00159 */
00160 
00161 extern uint32 OS_BSPGetTimerLow32Rollover(void);
00162 /*
00163 ** OS_BSPGetTimerLow32Rollover provides the number that the least significant
00164 ** 32 bits of the 64 bit time stamp returned by OS_BSPGet_Timebase rolls over.
00165 ** If the lower 32 bits rolls at 1 second, then the OS_BSP_TIMER_LOW32_ROLLOVER
00166 ** will be 1000000.  if the lower 32 bits rolls at its maximum value (2^32) then
00167 ** OS_BSP_TIMER_LOW32_ROLLOVER will be 0.
00168 */
00169 
00170 extern void OS_BSPGet_Timebase(uint32 *Tbu, uint32 *Tbl);
00171 /*
00172 ** OS_BSPGet_Timebase
00173 */
00174 
00175 extern uint32 OS_BSPGet_Dec(void);
00176 /*
00177 ** OS_BSPGet_Dec
00178 */
00179 
00180 
00181 extern int32 OS_BSPInitProcessorReservedMemory(uint32 RestartType );
00182 /*
00183 ** OS_BSPInitProcessorReservedMemory initializes all of the memory in the
00184 ** BSP that is preserved on a processor reset. The memory includes the
00185 ** Critical Data Store, the ES Reset Area, the Volatile Disk Memory, and
00186 ** the User Reserved Memory. In general, the memory areas will be initialized
00187 ** ( cleared ) on a Power On reset, and preserved during a processor reset.
00188 */
00189 
00190 extern int32 OS_BSPGetCDSSize(uint32 *SizeOfCDS);
00191 /*
00192 ** OS_BSPGetCDSSize fetches the size of the OS Critical Data Store area.
00193 */
00194 
00195 extern int32 OS_BSPWriteToCDS(void *PtrToDataToWrite, uint32 CDSOffset, uint32 NumBytes);
00196 /*
00197 ** OS_BSPWriteToCDS writes to the CDS Block.
00198 */
00199 
00200 extern int32 OS_BSPReadFromCDS(void *PtrToDataToRead, uint32 CDSOffset, uint32 NumBytes);
00201 /*
00202 ** OS_BSPReadFromCDS reads from the CDS Block
00203 */
00204 
00205 extern int32 OS_BSPGetResetArea (void *PtrToResetArea, uint32 *SizeOfResetArea);
00206 /*
00207 ** OS_BSPGetResetArea returns the location and size of the ES Reset information area.
00208 ** This area is preserved during a processor reset and is used to store the
00209 ** ER Log, System Log and reset related variables
00210 */
00211 
00212 extern int32 OS_BSPGetUserReservedArea(void *PtrToUserArea, uint32 *SizeOfUserArea );
00213 /*
00214 ** OS_BSPGetUserReservedArea returns the location and size of the memory used for the cFE
00215 ** User reserved area.
00216 */
00217 
00218 extern int32 OS_BSPGetVolatileDiskMem(void *PtrToVolDisk, uint32 *SizeOfVolDisk );
00219 /*
00220 ** OS_BSPGetVolatileDiskMem returns the location and size of the memory used for the cFE
00221 ** volatile disk.
00222 */
00223 
00224 extern int32 OS_BSPGetKernelTextSegmentInfo(void *PtrToKernelSegment, uint32 *SizeOfKernelSegment);
00225 /*
00226 ** OS_BSPGetKernelTextSegmentInfo returns the location and size of the kernel memory.
00227 */
00228 
00229 extern int32 OS_BSPGetCFETextSegmentInfo(void *PtrToCFESegment, uint32 *SizeOfCFESegment);
00230 /*
00231 ** OS_BSPGetCFETextSegmentInfo returns the location and size of the kernel memory.
00232 */
00233 
00234 extern void OS_BSPWatchdogInit(void);
00235 /*
00236 ** OS_BSPWatchdogInit configures the watchdog timer.
00237 */
00238 
00239 extern void OS_BSPWatchdogEnable(void);
00240 /*
00241 ** OS_BSPWatchdogEnable enables the watchdog timer.
00242 */
00243 
00244 extern void OS_BSPWatchdogDisable(void);
00245 /*
00246 ** OS_BSPWatchdogDisable disables the watchdog timer.
00247 */
00248 
00249 extern void OS_BSPWatchdogService(uint32 ExpireTime);
00250 /*
00251 ** OS_BSPWatchdogService sets the watchdog timer to a count that corresponds to the
00252 ** millisecond time given in the parameter.
00253 */
00254 
00255 extern void OS_BSPPanic(int32 ErrorCode);
00256 /*
00257 ** OS_BSPPanic is called by the cFE Core startup code when it needs to abort the
00258 ** cFE startup. This should not be called by applications.
00259 */
00260 
00261 extern int32 OS_BSPInitSSR(uint32 bus, uint32 device, char *DeviceName );
00262 /*
00263 ** OS_BSPInitSSR will initialize the Solid state recorder memory for a particular platform
00264 */
00265 
00266 extern int32 OS_BSPDecompress( char * srcFileName, char * dstFileName );
00267 /*
00268 ** OS_BSPDecompress will uncompress the source file to the file specified in the
00269 ** destination file name. The Decompress uses the "gzip" algorithm. Files can
00270 ** be compressed using the "gzip" program available on almost all host platforms.
00271 */
00272 
00273 extern void  OS_BSPAttachExceptions(void);
00274 /*
00275 ** OS_BSPAttachExceptions will setup the exception environment for the chosen platform
00276 ** On a board, this can be configured to look at a debug flag or switch in order to
00277 ** keep the standard OS exeption handlers, rather than restarting the system
00278 */
00279 
00280 
00281 extern void OS_BSPSetDefaultExceptionEnvironment(void);
00282 /*
00283 **
00284 **   OS_BSPSetDefaultExceptionEnvironment defines the CPU and FPU exceptions that are enabled for each cFE Task/App
00285 **
00286 **   Notes: The exception environment is local to each task Therefore this must be
00287 **          called for each task that that wants to do floating point and catch exceptions
00288 */
00289
